data.title: Rural municipalities open to paying more for policing: SARM
data.meta_description: People living in rural Saskatchewan pay about 20 per cent as much for policing as those living in the province's largest cities, but that could start to change as concerns about "out of control" crime in remote areas intensify.
data.text:
Article content

People living in rural Saskatchewan pay about 20 per cent as much for policing as people living in the province’s largest cities, but that could start to change as concerns about “out of control” crime in remote areas intensify.

Saskatchewan’s 296 rural municipalities would likely be open to paying more for policing, provided higher fees translate into better service, according to the president of the Saskatchewan Association of Rural Municipalities (SARM).

“We have been asking for more police officers … I think in most cases RMs wouldn’t mind contributing a bit more,” Ray Orb said Monday, noting that the RCMP are “stretched quite thin” in some remote areas of the province.

Saskatchewan budgeted $180.6 million to support the RCMP this year, of which $60.1 million was earmarked for law enforcement in RMs and small urban municipalities, representing 76 per cent of the total cost, according to the government.

That translates into annual per capita costs of $69.93 in jurisdictions with an RCMP detachment and $43.26 in areas without a permanent police presence. Both figures have increased by 33 per cent over the last five years.

However, the cost of rural policing stands in stark contrast to that of a major urban police force. The per capita cost of policing Saskatoon is expected to be $390 next year, while Regina’s is estimated to be $381.

Asked about the gulf between rural and urban costs, Orb said while there are differences, such as geography and the fact that cities with their own police forces can collect revenue from fines, rural crime “has to be addressed one way or another.”

That likely means reinvigorating the Rural Crime Watch and Community Safety Officer programs while continuing to push the provincial government for more RCMP officers in rural areas, he said.

Rural crime and policing have become major issues in the seven months since Colten Boushie, a 22-year-old man from Red Pheasant First Nation, was shot to death in a farmyard north of Biggar.

Gerald Stanley, a 55-year-old farmer, pleaded not guilty to a second-degree murder charge in connection with Boushie’s death, which has highlighted strained relations between indigenous and non-indigenous communities in the province.

Federation of Sovereign Indigenous Nations (FSIN) vice-chief Kim Jonathan, who last week condemned a SARM resolution to lobby the federal government for expanded self-defence rights, said it’s important for communities to find common ground.

That means funding programs that encourage conversation between indigenous and non-indigenous people and police, rather than simply hiring more officers to make more arrests, Jonathan said.

Through a spokesman, Saskatchewan RCMP commanding officer Curtis Zablocki declined an interview request on Monday. The spokesman said the force could not immediately comment on concerns about rural policing.

Saskatchewan Justice Minister Gordon Wyant said while hiring more RCMP officers could be “part of the answer,” any viable long-term solution will include a range of new policies, measures and programs.

That could mean shifting “low-risk” policing activities to other agencies, funding programs like Rural Crime Watch and encouraging all interested parties to demonstrate leadership and build relationships, he said.

A caucus committee chaired by Saskatchewan Party MLA Herb Cox is expected to release its report on policing in the province this month. Wyant said the government will “do what we can to work on solutions to help alleviate concerns in rural Saskatchewan.”
